message: :%s/\t/  /g <3 Turn tabs into 2 spaces for the whole file.
@Zolomon If you already have your tab settings in your vimrc you can also just do :retab
@ptone Oh, didn't know that - thanks! (VIM newbie)
@Zolomon That's what this group is all about sharing vim knowledge. I've been using vim for a year and a bit and I still keep learning new things I didn't have a clue about.
@ptone Wow. :retab...cheers, that is going to save me a lot of time.
What do you set your tab settings in your vimrc?

filetype plugin indent on

" ALL-IMPORTANT TAB SETTINGS
set smarttab " If at the beginning of the line, use shiftwidth instead of tabstop
set expandtab " SOFT-TABS FTW!!!
set tabstop=8 " Leave this 8 for legacy reasons; should also make it easier to spot the hated hard-tab.
set softtabstop=4 " Real men use 4-space indents
set shiftwidth=4 " Now we can use < and > in visual (marking) mode to block indent/unindent regions; also used at the beginning of lines thanks to smarttab

And then I have the following in ~/.vim/after/ftplugin/ruby.vim:

set ai et ts=2 sw=2 tw=0
I believe that's about a day or two old.
It figured it out on its own, btw. I didn't do anything special to trigger it.
@gthank Wow when did convore.com add code syntax? :D
There's a big topic on a "shiny new feature",iirc.
For the record, I'd recommend using the bang version: :retab!

With the bang, you can go both ways (tabs to spaces, or spaces to tabs - depending on the current `et` setting). Without the bang, you can only go one way. I always forget which way, so make it a habit to always include the bang.
